Award.AwardTitle: Controlling the Hierarchal Structure of Light-Harvesting Chromophore Aggregates
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Jeanne McHale and her graduate students will address fundamental questions about the hierarchal structures of light-harvesting chromophore aggregates and their potential to improve the efficiency of solar energy conversion. Based on previous studies of porphyrin aggregates, the PI has developed the hypothesis that molecular flexibility directs local supramolecular structure while environment determines the longer range order. To pursue the objective of controlling and optimizing the optical and energy-transfer properties of light-harvesting aggregates (LHAs), the following four specific aims will be pursued: 1. Use resonance Raman spectroscopy to reveal molecular conformation of flexible carotenoids in aggregates whose supramolecular structure depends on solvent. 2. Prepare LHAs with controlled size and shape using nanostructured metal and metal oxide supports and examine their optical properties using ensemble and single-aggregate resonance Raman spectroscopy. 3. Prepare self-assembled heteroaggregates of energy donors (carotenoids) with energy acceptors (porphyrins) and explore their energy transfer and excited electronic states. 4. Exploit LHAs as energy donors and/or sensitizers for dye-sensitized solar energy conversion to achieve improved light harvesting. These experiments will result in fundamental knowledge required to exploit the extended wavelength response of LHAs in solar photovoltaic devices. The proposal builds on the PI's longstanding research in resonance Raman studies of photoinduced electron transfer, excited state dynamics, and chromophore aggregation, as well as more recent breakthroughs in solar energy conversion using plant pigments.

The project will also extend previous education and outreach efforts aimed at broadening participation in science and specifically in solar energy research. The PI and her graduate students will continue to contribute to WSU's outreach program to Native American and Hispanic students: "Pumping up the Math and Science Program." The PI and her students will also partner with the Palouse Clearwater Environmental Institute to grow "solar vegetables" as sources of plant pigments for demonstration solar cells to be used in presentations to local schools and nonprofit groups. It is the goal of both these projects to recruit future scientists to face the technical challenges of powering the planet with sunlight.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chlorophyll is of course the answer to the question a lot of teachers and parents get from schoolchildren, namely: “Why is grass green?” However, while it goes beyond the usual explanation, the reality is that 99 percent of the chlorophyll in photosynthetic organisms is there just to collect sunlight and funnel it to the business end of the apparatus: the 1% of chlorophyll that participates in making fuel. The job of harvesting the energy from sunlight and directing it to the reaction center is done by assemblies of chlorophyll molecules that have been exquisitely designed by Nature to collect sunlight of specific wavelengths.  In the laboratory, artificial assemblies of related molecules, porphyrins, can be prepared and studied in order to reveal the link between the structural and optical properties of light-harvesting complexes similar to those found in photosynthetic bacteria. In this research, we have prepared aggregates of a porphyrin TSPP which form spontaneously in water solution in the presence of salt and acid. Our goal has been to learn how to control the light-harvesting and energy transfer properties of assemblies like this so that they could be exploited in solar energy conversion. One limitation to the efficiency of converting sunlight to fuel or electricity is the challenge of harvesting light at longer (red) wavelengths. Chromophore aggregates however can be prepared which absorb a significant portion of the red end of the solar spectrum, and offer hope for improved efficiency of artificial photosynthesis.  Using imaging and spectroscopy, we have learned that water plays an integral role in the collective behavior of these aggregates, helping to distribute the energy harvested from light over  a larger number of molecules, facilitating energy transfer. We have learned that the light harvesting properties of these aggregates are tuned by their hierarchical structure: molecules first assemble into small subunits, driven by electrostatic interactions, which dictate the wavelengths of light absorbed. These subunits are then induced to form helices which connect the subunits through water-mediated hydrogen bonds. This results in shifts to the spectrum of light absorbed. Further bundling of the helices, induced by salts such as sodium chloride, results in further extension of the optical response to the red. Using various imaging techniques, including optical microscopy and electron microscopy, we observe the overall morphology of aggregates deposited from aqueous solutions of different salts or acid. We have been able to learn how different salts cause bundling of aggregates and are able to understand the effect of salts based on how different ions interact with water and with the porphyrin molecules. The insight these experiments provide will guide efforts to tailor molecular structure and solution environment to prepare chromophore aggregates with desired optical properties.  In addition to our scientific research, as part of this grant we participated in outreach events to engage middle and high school students in the science of light, color, and solar energy conversion. These efforts included working with first-generation college students as summer interns in the lab, presenting solar energy demonstrations to students who are members of the Nez Perce tribe, and organizing a summer camp workshop, Build a Rainbow Solar Panel, for WSU’s Cougar Quest program.
